comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I think you mean West, not East Circular Quay? :)

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] The image is flipped the wrong way, so when you flip it over you notice it is East Circular quay. But to be honest, the give away was the fact that the P&O wharf was where the Opera House now stands. Check out this map via [http://www.flickr.com/photos/national_library_of_australia_commons/], isn't it pretty? :-)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Hmm ... are you sure? I think the presence of the P&O liner is a red herring! If you flip the image the text of the "Bank of New South Wales" sign becomes reversed. Note also the G.P.O. clock tower. I'm convinced it is this wharf at West Circular Quay (which incidentally shows a P&O liner) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/7736995684/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I vote for Circular Quay West, like the 'Aurora' - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8078402686/] Also betting on Friday 15/7/1932 for departure at 4pm from No.4 wharf (see long winter shadows and coats) - what does the GPO clock say? - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16898540

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Think you're both right! A convincing argument :) Plus the buildings look the same in that STRATHAIRD pic. Hood must have just written on the back of it so that's why it appears reversed.

That date is consistent with the women's clothing, so it is possible that is the correct date. Although it could also be 17 June 1933 at 11:30 am. But do you think it is more likely to be the inaugural visit based on the level of celebrations going on in the pic?
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Ha! It s a tight race, but I reckon Samuel J. Hood was interested in the maiden / inaugural voyage of the 'Corfu'.  

Pellethepoet?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] As we know the exact geographical location, and we have a reference shadow (the man in the foreground), there is a way of dating the photo to the exact time and date. archivesoutside.records.nsw.gov.au/using-shadows-to-date-... archivesoutside.records.nsw.gov.au/using-shadows-to-date-... But don't ask me how to do it!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Yes, I could never understand that method. I tried using this small program aie.org.au/Content/NavigationMenu/Resources/EnergyData/So... . Latitude is -33.8574 (from GoogleMaps link URL) For 15 July at 16:00 the sun is at 28.44 degrees. By 17:00 it is at 14.64 degrees. ie too sharp an angle for this photo. For 17 June at 11:00 the sun is at 62.61 degrees. By 12:00 it is at 66.63 degrees. ie too blunt an angle for this photo. Hmmm. Expert required! Any navigators at the ANMM?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Hmmm, it is a tricky one. Seeing as the only other departure I could find was 25 July 1935 at 8am at Pyrmont, the 4pm and 11:30am seem to be the only options. Fascinating way to identify photographs though. Thanks for the links to the archives outside blog via [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/]. A fantastic blog!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
